newsitem.title: FRANCE: French court upholds BA Gulf hostages compensation.
newsitem.headline: French court upholds BA Gulf hostages compensation.

text.p: A French appeals court on Tuesday upheld a lower court ruling ordering British Airways to compensate 61 Gulf War hostages for landing them in Iraqi hands in occupied Kuwait, justice sources said.

The 61 French nationals and foreign residents of France were among 364 people aboard a BA flight from London which landed at Kuwait airport on August 2, 1990 -- four hours after Iraqi invaders entered the emirate.

The British airline had appealed against last year's order to pay the hostages 400,000 to 600,000 francs ($80,000 to $120,000) each in damages, according to the time they spent in captivity -- a total of 26 million francs ($5.2 million).
The plaintiffs charged that BA had committed a "severe error" and demanded compensation for the mental anguish they suffered.

British Airways argued it had no way of knowing that the invasion was underway. It said the hostages had already been paid compensation of around 30,000 francs ($6,000) each out of a French state fund set up for victims of terrorist or similar attacks.

Iraqi soldiers seized the Boeing 747, and its passengers were held hostage for up to three months, some being used as human shields against allied bombing of strategic Iraqi sites. ($1=5.057 French Franc)
